runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the picture shows two animals that live on a farma horse and a turkey. Explain that a turkey is a type of bird. Have students find the turkey inthe picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is movement or a physical activity that is good for your body.
Example: I ride my bike for
Ask: What do you do for
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names how Tyler feels once he learns about Thanksgiving. (disturbed)
What do the turkeys do for exercise? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Tyler says that being healthy is the most important gift. What does he mean? Do you agree? Why or why not?
Why is it important to exercise? How else do you keep your body healthy?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that a debate is a discussion in which people express different opinions about a topic or an issue. Students might debate whether or not daily homework should be required.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is to talk about something in order to make a decision or share ideas.
about what to have for lunch.
What is something you might have a
about with a parent or family member?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what the turkey uses to defend, or protect, itself. (spurs)
How is a turkeys call different than an eagles call? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What kind of information are Eagle and Turkey presenting during this discussion? Why is this information important to their debate?
Which bird do you think won the debate? Give a reason to support your answer.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 5 and 6.
Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence.
Have students echo-read the sentences, replicating your phrasing.
Read the title. Point out that the text is formatted in short lines. Explain that this text is a poem. Explain that a vote is a way to express, or show, your choice.
For the first reading, have students echo-read the text with you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can take turns reading each stanza, or group of lines.
Prompt students to find all the words with r-controlled vowel
spellings in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about how voting gives us the chance to choose who our leaders will be.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to choose, or make a choice.
the food we want to eat.
If you could choose any pet, which animal would you
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
What do we pick when we vote in elections? (leaders)
What kind of government do we have? What happens in a democracy? Find sentences that answer these questions.
What should people think about when they select, or choose, a leader?
What is an issue you care about? How will you decide which leaders to select?
Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word perfect. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (question mark), 2 (period), and 10 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echo-read the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that when people vote for leaders, they mark their choices on a ballot. This text includes an example of a ballot. Authors include examples to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the sample ballot.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the sample ballot.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a boy who visits his dad at the firehouse.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a person or animal someone spends a lot of time with.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the job Turners dad has. (firefighter)
How did the new guy end up at the firehouse? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do you think the firefighters chose to keep the kitten as a companion? Do you think a kitten makes a good companion at a firehouse? Why or why not?
Which animal would you choose to be your companion at home?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is an informational text that gives facts about where the president of the United States lives. Ask students what they think might be inside the presidents house.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means not usual, or not common.
thing to see at school, but not at a zoo.
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the place in the White House to watch movies. (theater)
How can you tell the White House is very large? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why can we say that some White House pets were quite unusual?
What did you find unusual about the presidents house? Why do you think the president needs a house with so many rooms and bathrooms and such a large dining room?
What else would you like to know about the White House? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
